  • Articles
    ahr: computes AHR under NPH assumptions and (stratified) populations expected_accrual: computes the expected cumulative enrollment (accrual) given a set of piecewise constant enrollment rates and times expected_event: compute expected number of events at 1 time point expected_time: compute time when a targeted number of events is made fixed_design_*: compute sample size/power of a fixed design gs_b: specify fixed boundaries in group sequential designs gs_info_ahr: compute statistical information by the AHR method gs_power_npe: derives bounds and crossing probabilities for group sequential designs under NPH assumptions Computing spending boundaries in group sequential design summary & as_gt: summarize group sequential design

    expected_accrual: computes the expected cumulative enrollment (accrual) given a set of piecewise constant enrollment rates and times

    Yujie Zhao

    usage-expected-accrual.Rmd
    library(tibble)
library(dplyr)
library(gsDesign2)

    Introduction of expected_accrual()

    Use cases of expected_accrual()

    Example 1

    For the enrollment in the first 3 months, it is exactly \(3 \times 5 = 15\).

    expected_accrual(
  time = 3,
  enroll_rate = define_enroll_rate(duration = c(3, 3, 18), rate = c(5, 10, 20))
)
    ## [1] 15

    Example 2

    For the enrollment in the first 6 months, it is exactly \(3 \times 5 + 3 \times 10 = 45\).

    expected_accrual(
  time = 6,
  enroll_rate = define_enroll_rate(duration = c(3, 3, 18), rate = c(5, 10, 20))
)
    ## [1] 45

    Example 3

    For the enrollment in the first 24 months, it is exactly \(3 \times 5 + 3 \times 10 + 18 * 20 = 405\).

    expected_accrual(
  time = 24,
  enroll_rate = define_enroll_rate(duration = c(3, 3, 18), rate = c(5, 10, 20))
)
    ## [1] 405

    Example 4

    For the enrollment after 24 months, it is the same as that from the 24 months, since the enrollment is stopped.

    expected_accrual(
  time = 25,
  enroll_rate = define_enroll_rate(duration = c(3, 3, 18), rate = c(5, 10, 20))
)
    ## [1] 405

    Example 5

    Instead of compute the enrolled subjects one time point by one time point, we can also compute it once.

    expected_accrual(
  time = c(3, 6, 24, 25),
  enroll_rate = define_enroll_rate(duration = c(3, 3, 18), rate = c(5, 10, 20))
)
    ## [1]  15  45 405 405

    Inner Logic of expected_accrual()
